title-group.article-title: Machine learning analysis of a large set of homopolymers to predict glass transition temperatures

abstract.p: Glass transition temperature of polymers, Tg, is an important thermophysical property, which sometimes can be difficult to measure experimentally. In this regard, data-driven machine learning approaches are important alternatives to assess Tg values, in a high-throughput way. In this study, a large dataset of more than 900 polymers with reported glass transition temperature (Tg) was assembled from various public sources in order to develop a predictive model depicting the structure-property relationships. The collected dataset was curated, explored via cluster analysis, and then split into training and test sets for validation purposes and then polymer structures characterized by molecular descriptors. To find the models, several machine learning techniques, including multiple linear regression (MLR), k-nearest neighbor (k-NN), support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), gaussian processes for regression (GPR), and multi-layer perceptron (MLP) were explored. As result, a model with the subset of 15 descriptors accurately predicting the glass transition temperatures was developed. The electronic effect indices were determined to be important properties that positively contribute to the Tg values. The SVM-based model showed the best performance with determination coefficients (R2) of 0.813 and 0.770, for training and test sets, respectively. Also, the SVM model showed the lowest estimation error, RMSE = 0.062. In addition, the developed structure-property model was implemented as a web app to be used as an online computational tool to design and evaluate new homopolymers with desired glass transition profiles.

Glass transition temperatures (Tg) of polymers are important thermophysical descriptors, but they can be difficult to determine experimentally. Here, the authors develop a data-driven support vector machine structure-property model to assess Tg values in a high-throughput manner, and implement the model into a web app.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The glass transition temperature (Tg) is one of the most important properties of polymeric materials and indicates an approximate temperature below which a macromolecular system changes from a relatively soft, flexible and rubbery state to a hard, brittle and glass-like one1. The Tg value also determines the utilization limits of many rubbers and thermoplastic materials. Besides, the drastic changes in the mobility of the molecules in different glassy states (from the frozen to the thawed state) affect many other chemical and physical properties, such as mechanical modulus, acoustical properties, specific heat, viscosity, mechanical energy absorption, density, dielectric coefficients, viscosity and the gases and liquids diffusion rate in the polymer material2,3. The change of these mechanical properties also specifies the employment of the material and the manufacturing process.

Nowadays it is of utmost importance to approximate Tg value for polymers in confined geometries4. However, in many cases, it is a challenge to experimentally develop and detect glass transition of new polymer structures due to long, time-consuming and expensive experiments. Fortunately, since a relatively large number of experimental data is available, it is now possible to use these data for benchmarking a new approach in order to accurately estimate the required property (i.e. Tg) in a cost-effective manner5,6.

In this sense, a machine learning (ML)-based quantitative structure-property relationship (QSPR) approach, which allows to correlate the structure of compounds with physicochemical properties, can be suitable for modeling properties of chemicals7–11 and polymers12–17, including Tg values10,18,19. Computational predictions prior to experimental tests could help to improve the trial-and-error synthesis process of new polymers. More importantly, once developed, QSPR models could be used for screening a vast number of structures and for identifying new polymeric materials with desired Tg20–22.

Several previously published studies have attempted to predict Tg values. The most widely known model of theoretical Tg estimation is the one reported by Bicerano23. The author developed a Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) model (R2 = 0.97) with 13 structural parameters for a dataset of 320 polymers. However the main pitfall in this study is the lack of an external dataset to properly validate the model24. In another study, Hamerton et al. used a dataset of 66 polyarylene ether sulfones and obtained a QSPR model with correlation coefficient of 0.98 and 0.86, for the training and prediction sets, respectively25. Mattioni and Jurs26 developed another QSPR model with 10 descriptors, on a data set of 165 polymers (R2 = 0.98), using Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and the performance for a prediction set of 17 compounds was R2 = 0.92. Karuth et al. developed an integrated framework to validate the predictive model of Tg of 100 diverse homopolymers polymers using coarse grain molecular dynamics16. Other models that can be mentioned are those reported by Ramon-Garcia et al.27,28. for a data set of 84 homopolymers.

As can be seen from the survey, most of the published studies are only based on congeneric or small datasets. This fact limits the applicability, as well as the screening ability, of developed ML-based QSPR models. To date, the prediction of Tg values of polymers on the basis of repeating unit structures continue to be a challenge29. Although for the last few years some interesting studies based on transformers, natural language processing techniques have been published, where specific deep learning algorithms like convolutional networks were applied, the factors that govern the glass transition temperature are not analyzed in detail30,31. For example, a recently published study where authors applied a Graph Convolutional Neural Network (GCNN) was using 600 data points for the prediction of Tg values, achieving a R2 = 0.88, which is good but low comparing to the complexity of the GCNN algorithms and non-transparency of the model32.

In current work we attempted to expand the chemical space by assembling a relatively large dataset of homopolymers with Tg values (more than 900 data points), compiled from published manuscripts and publicly available sources. We then explored the structure-property relationships of collected data by applying several ML-based QSPR approaches in order to develop new computational tools to accurately predict the Tg values for the polymer structures of interest. To this end, internal and external test sets were applied to the QSPR models to ensure good-of-fitness and predictive ability. Furthermore, structure-property correlation analysis was performed to gain some clues in order to design novel polymeric materials with desired Tg values.

Moreover, in this work, we developed a web application to facilitate the prediction of the Tg values for any homopolymer, useful for experimental or computational chemists who are interested in prediction of Tg of their polymer systems in advance of synthesis. To our best knowledge, no previous studies offered this feature.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this study we investigated a dataset of 902 homopolymers with Tg experimental data, compiled from publicly available sources. We then applied ML-based QSAR approach to explore the structure-property relationship within the dataset. A structure-property relationship analysis was performed to gain new knowledge which could be used to design novel polymeric materials with desired Tg values.

The list of all the polymers together with their reported experimental Tg values is shown in Supplementary Data 1. In addition, Fig. 1 shows the histogram of the distribution of the log (Tg) values in the training and test sets. As can be observed from the plot, the dependent variable is very close to the normal distribution, therefore allowing this data to be used for linear modeling process.Fig. 1Distribution of log(Tg(K)) values.
Distribution of log(Tg(K)) values in the training and prediction series.

A second diagram was built in order to display the distribution of the number of atoms per each repeating unit (RU) in the polymer, for both the training and test sets (see Fig. 2). As it can be observed from the figure, the number of polymers with less than 20 atoms in repeating unit represent the majority of the dataset, comprising the highest quantity of RU falling inside these groups with 606 polymers for a 67.03% of the total dataset. A decrease in numbers can be observed for the groups, with less than 10 polymers having 20 or more atoms in repeating unit in each bar, counting for 155 polymers in the range of 20–40 atoms in repeating unit, representing the 17.14% of the 902 polymers. Moreover, starting from 60 atoms and more in repeating unit (number of atoms >60 in repeating unit), the quantity of polymers is reduced to 5 or less, with a total of 35 polymers which is equivalent to 3.87% of the dataset. In addition, in Fig. 2 the representative chemical structure of the polymers in the training set with the lowest, medium and highest atom counts in repeating units are shown.Fig. 2Distribution of data set based on atom counts.
Distribution of quantity of atoms with respect to the repeating units.

In order to demonstrate the structural diversity of the dataset, a joining cluster analysis (CA) was performed33. The dendrogram is shown in Fig. 3, which is generated by using the Euclidean distance between cases (X-axis), and the linkage distance is calculated by Ward’s method (Y-axis), illustrating the results of the k-NNCA (using as input the 15-dimensional descriptors ‘space). This dendrogram shows different subsets, which illustrate the molecular variability of the selected polymeric structures in this dataset. In addition, a Violin Plot was used to visualize the distribution of the data and its probability density (see Supplementary Fig. 3 in Supplementary Information 1)34. This chart is a result of the Box Plot and a Density Plot combination, that is rotated and placed on each side. In this graph, we show the data distribution shape, where a thick black bar in the center is an interquartile range, a thin black line extended from it depicts the 95% confidence intervals, and the white dot is a median. While the Box Plots are the most commonly used, they are limited in the representation of the data, as their visual simplicity tends to hide significant details about how values in the dataset are distributed.Fig. 3Dendrogram for the dataset.
A vertical dendrogram of the cluster analysis.

sec.title: Development of QSPR model
sec.p:
After completing all preliminary steps (structure preparation, descriptors generation, and elimination of constant and near-constant descriptors), the MLR analysis was used to develop a first QSPR model for the prediction of the glass transition temperature. The quality of the QSPR-MLR model was determined by examining the statistical parameters of the regression in internal procedures and in the test set (See Table 1).Table 1
Statistical parameters for the QSPR-MLR model
N(TS/ES)R2trainR2testRMSEtrainRMSEtestFIntercept
683/2190.6510.6170.0850.08682.82+1.939
N Number of compounds in training set (TS) and test set (ES).
RMSE root means square error.

From this model, N is the size of the data set; R2train, the determination coefficient of the training set; F, the Fisher ratio; RMSE, the root mean square error24; and R2test is the square correlation coefficient for the test set.

The model’s performance shows a squared regression coefficient (R2) value of 0.651, it explains more than 65% of the experimental variance of the glass transition temperature in the data, using the log(Tg) as a dependent variable with F = 82.82 and p = 0.001. As a first step, the MLR technique was chosen to develop the QSPR model, since this technique is simple and easy to interpret by analyzing the factors that are likely to govern the log(Tg) of the compounds by the descriptor’s interpretation in the regression model. Therefore, it is useful to link the structural characteristics of the repeating units to describe the relationship between the structure and the glass transition temperature in the regression analysis. In Table 2, the definitions of the molecular descriptors included in the QSPR-MLR model are provided.Table 2
Description of the molecular descriptors
DescriptorsDescriptionDescriptor family
TE1Topographic electronic descriptorCharge descriptors
Mor31vSignal 31/weighted by van der Waals volume3D-MoRSE descriptors
SpMax1_Bh(i)Largest eigenvalue n. 1 of Burden matrix weighted by ionization potentialBurden eigenvalues
SpDiam_B(e)Spectral diameter from Burden matrix weighted by Sanderson electronegativity2D matrix-based descriptors
SIC4Structural Information Content index (neighborhood symmetry of 4-order)Information indices
AACMean information index on atomic compositionInformation indices
piPC07Molecular multiple path count of order 7Walk and path counts
piPC05Molecular multiple path count of order 5Walk and path counts
S1K1-path Kier alpha-modified shape indexTopological indices
B03[C–N]Presence/absence of C–N at topological distance 32D Atom Pairs
Eig03_EAEigenvalue n. 3 from edge adjacency matEdge adjacency indices
SM11_EASpectral moment of order 11 from edge adjacency mat.Edge adjacency indices
SpMax_AEA(dm)Leading eigenvalue from augmented edge adjacency mat. weighted by dipole momentEdge adjacency indices
SpMax_EA(ri)Leading eigenvalue from edge adjacency mat. weighted by resonance integralEdge adjacency indices
nCsp2Number of sp2 hybridized Carbon atomsConstitutional indices

The linear relationship between the glass transition temperature of polymers (represented by value of log(Tg) and fifteen 0D-3D Dragon descriptors is shown in Fig. 4. In this plotted graph the contribution of each descriptor to the Tg value is visualized.Fig. 4Coefficient values MLR model.
Contributing positive and negative coefficient values for descriptors in the QSPR-MLR model for Tg prediction.

In Fig. 4 can be seen that nine descriptors: TE1, Mor31v, SpDiam_B(e), AA, piPC05, B03-[C–N], SpMax_AEA(dm), SpMax_EA(ri), and nCSp2 have a positive contribution to the Tg value (right side), while the other six descriptors: SpMax1_Bh(i), SIC4, piPC07, S1K, Eig03_EA, and SM11_EA have a negative influence on the investigated property, Tg.

Among the variables with positive values SpDiam_B(e) has the highest contribution, this variable is weighted by the Sanderson electronegativity, which means that this property plays a significant role in forming the Tg index. This fact is in agreement with previous results35. Although SpMax1_Bh(i) is a molecular descriptor, weighted by ionization potential that displays the highest negative effect, the descriptor’s behavior is closely related to the previously described descriptor because these properties are basically inversely correlating to each other. A positive effect is also observed in TE1 (topographic electronic descriptor); in SpMax_AEA(dm), a dipole moment weighted descriptor; and SpMax_EA(ri), which is weighted by the resonance integral value related to the energy of an electron in the field of 2 or more nuclei. These three descriptors are related to electronic effects and have a positive impact on Tg.

The piPC05 descriptor shows a positive relation with the dependent variable, i.e. Tg. The piPC05 is a topological descriptor that describes a molecular multiple path count of order 5 based on the structure, and related to molecular branching and size, as well as to molecular complexity of the graph (i.e. larger piPC05 implies a larger size and complex molecules). However, it is not very clear whether the Tg values increase with the complexity of the structures, as the model also contains the piPC07 descriptor with a negative contribution to Tg. A functional count index (number of sp2 hybridized Carbon atoms), nCsp2, contributes positively to the Tg. Another index, Mor31v which is weighted by van der Waals volume, also increases the Tg value of polymers. The same with B03[C–N] descriptor, which accounts for the presence/absence of C–N fragment at a topological distance 3, indicating that the presence of nitrogen atoms positively contributes to Tg.

It is important to highlight that nCsp2 is a constitutional index, which encodes the number of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms and has a positive contribution to Tg property. The nCsp2 contribution can be explained by the presence of double bonds in the polymer backbone, which are limiting the rotation, unlike freely rotatable C–C single bonds, and the presence of double bonds increasing the glass transition temperature since it makes the polymer more rigid and more energy is needed to put the polymer in motion36.

Although the obtained QSPR-MLR model shows adequate statistics for the training set, cross-validation and test set with values (R2train, = 0.65 and R2test = 0.61), receiving higher R2 values is still very important to make more accurate predictions of Tg property in further virtual screening steps. In this sense, in this work the different ML techniques were further applied and a set of additional predictive models for the Tg is developed. Most widely used and effective techniques, like k-nearest neighbors (k-NN) and other more complex algorithms, such as support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), Gaussian Processes for Regression (GPR), multi-layer perceptron (MLP), regression trees (RT), are applied in this work. Fig. 5 shows the comparative results for each QSPR model based on ML technique (including MLR).Fig. 5Performance of machine learning models.
Comparative histogram plot of the performance of developed machine learning models. Multiple linear regression (MLR), k-nearest neighbor (k-NN), support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), gaussian processes for regression (GPR), multi-layer perceptron (MLP).

As can be observed in Fig. 5 all regression functions in the training set for each ML technique (k-NN, SVM, RF, GPR, and MLP) have adequate performance values (0.65–0.81) and RMSE below 0.09. For the training set the SVM model showed the best-squared correlation coefficient (R2train = 0.813) and the lowest RMSE = 0.062.

It is well known that the classification of all compounds by using only training dataset provides a quite useful assessment of the models’ performance, but it is not enough to provide a thorough criterion on the models’ prediction power towards new compounds or polymer’s repeating unit structures. For this reason, it is essential to use an independent test set to assess the predictive power of the developed models. For this reason, in this work the test set was applied and the Tg values of the polymers in test set were predicted by the developed QSPR-ML models, and results are shown in Fig. 5. The predictive R2ext values for the models were in a range 0.60–0.77, and all RMSE values for the test were below 0.1.

The performance of the QSPR-SVM model for the test set is superior to the rest of the QSPR-ML models (R2test = 0.77). This is in accordance with the recent studies, where SVM often shows high performances in machine learning studies37,38. A correlation plot generated for the SVM model is shown in Fig. 6. This figure shows a correlation between the observed and the predicted values, for both training and test sets. The QSPR-SVM model was also deployed as a web application on the Streamlit platform under the name “Tg_ml_predictor” (https://mltgpredictor-9tzz6kfng8gv5luxfuomie.streamlit.app/). In addition, Fig. 7 shows the impact of each descriptor to the target variable, which is in agreement with the results displayed by the QSPR-MLR model.Fig. 6Observed vs predicted correlation for the SVM regressor.
Observed vs predicted correlation for the SVM regressor. Blue dots (training set), and yellow dots (validation set).Fig. 7ALE plots for SVM model.
Descriptors weights represented by ALE plot for the SVM regressor.

sec.title: Application of developed QSPR-SVM model to predict the Tg index
sec.p:
The recently developed AI-based approaches in computer-aided molecular design such as ML-model-guided virtual screenings have a great importance in the prediction of physicochemical properties of materials. In this work, with the aim to externally validate the QSPR-SVM model, we used a completely independent dataset, i.e. a series of structurally different precursors extracted from SciFinder after the model development, with experimentally measured glass transition temperatures, using the commercial availability as one of the filtering criteria. A total of 369 precursor polymer structures were chosen, followed by the curation of data where those with salts and mixtures were removed, keeping 179 precursor polymer structures. In addition, the applicability domain for the new structures were checked by the range of descriptors’ values in the training set and only a set of 28 structures with high confidence values (structures are located inside the AD), were selected to be evaluated with the SVM model resulting in R2 = 0.712. As it can be seen (Fig. 8, 9), there is a wide structural diversity in the selected subset allowing to predict Tg values from different non-congenerical datasets of polymers, which was one of the main drawbacks in previous studies. The obtained result of predicted Tg values validates the current methodology for the ability of fast and adequate prediction of glass transition temperatures for new homopolymers.Fig. 8Representative structures 1–16 as repeating units (RU) from the virtual screening.
The set 1–16 of molecular structures of precursors (monomeric units) that are used in virtual screening procedure.Fig. 9Representative structures 17–28 as repeating units (RU) from the virtual screening.
The set 17–28 of molecular structures of precursors (monomeric units) that are used in virtual screening procedure.

To conclude, the selected SVM model exhibited the best squared correlation coefficients for the training set (R2train = 0.813) and for the test sets (R2test = 0.77). Moreover, the same QSPR-SVM model exhibited a similar level of prediction for the completely external dataset of collected data, with resulting R2 = 0.712. This is an impressive result for the independent dataset with a wide structural diversity. The obtained result validates the developed QSPR-SVM model and validates the current applied methodology for the ability of fast and adequate prediction of glass transition temperatures for new homopolymers.

sec.title: Data collection and formatting
sec.p: A dataset of 1298 homopolymers with reported Tg values was initially collected from various public sources by gathering the data published using the OSRA (Optical Structure Recognition Application) platform (https://cactus.nci.nih.gov/cgi-bin/osra/index.cgi). After discarding the data with similar identity (having the same ID: name or SMILES notation) and keeping structures with unique Tg, the remaining dataset included 984 structures.

All structures were then submitted to a rigorous curation process following the guidelines established by Fourches et al.39,40. These data curation steps include the identification of a repeating unit, the removal of explicit hydrogen atoms, and the curation of tautomeric forms. These procedures were performed through the ChemAxon’s Standardizer package41.

The EdiSDF tool of the ISIDA/QSPR package42 was used together with ChemAxon software41 and RDKit cheminformatics package43 to check duplicate structures in the dataset. By this way, a set of 82 duplicate structures were detected, and removed using a prioritizing approach, where kept those values with the most accurate Tg value from the literature, resulting in the final data with 902 unique polymers. The id/names of the polymers together with experimental Tg values and SMILES notations of repeating units can be found in Supplementary Data 1. In our case the Tg values were transformed to logarithm (base 10) and noted as log Tg through all the manuscript, since this is the standard representation unit in most of the QSPR studies44.

The dataset of the polymers was then divided into training and test sets which comprised of 683 (~75%) and 219 polymers (25%), respectively. The choice of the series was done by a selection, using the target value in a descending order and selecting every third polymeric structure to add into the test set, which is a regular procedure for any machine learning or QSPR modeling study45.

sec.title: Descriptors generation
sec.p: Dragon46 software version 6.0, a well known in the cheminformatics field, was used to generate a set of descriptors for this dataset. The software provides more than 5000 diverse descriptors of more than 20 families (categories) corresponding to 0D-3D dimensional indices46,47. These molecular descriptors are essential for capturing many types of molecular properties. Using this large number of descriptors provides a broad feature space where the molecule’s shape, the electronic structure, topological properties and specific functional groups in the molecule are considered. In this way the likelihood of building predictive models that can learn the more relevant factors is increased.

In the next step, after removing the descriptors with missing values the set of 2883 descriptors is selected for further processing. A box plot for this set of 2883 descriptors was generated in order to check the behavior of each molecular descriptor (see Supplementary Fig. 1 in Supplementary Information 1). After that, several descriptors with a constant variance, near-constant values or correlation above 95% were removed from the further analysis (nearly 1000 descriptors). Supplementary Fig. 2 shows a box plot with the remaining set of 1957 molecular descriptors that were used as independent variables for the model development.

sec.title: Feature selection and multiple linear regression
sec.p: The feature selection procedures were performed using Genetic Algorithm (GA) that combined with multiple linear regression (MLR) modeling step. This preliminary feature selection based on GA-MLR35,44,48 was done using QSARINS 2.2 package49,50. In this case the GA variable selection algorithm started with a population of 500 random models and 2000 iterations to evolution with the mutation probability specified at 35%. After selecting a first subset of 15 descriptors, an MLR model was optimized, and this pool of variables was used for the development of additional machine learning models.

sec.title: Machine learning methods
sec.p: The machine learning methods show impressive performance in a wide diversity of studies involving automation, text classification and drug design51,52 In this study, numerous ML techniques were employed for the model development, that include: multiple linear regression (MLR), k-nearest neighbor (k-NN), support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), gaussian processes for regression (GPR), and multi-layer perceptron (MLP). For each ML method applied, various schemes for feature selection were examined using WEKA 3.7 environment53. The fundamental remarks and the details for parameter tuning of each one of the ML techniques together with the values obtained in the optimization process are summarized in Supplementary Note 1 of Supplementary Information 1.

In all cases the initial performance of the QSPR models was evaluated with statistical analysis parameters, such as: squared correlation coefficient R2, root-mean-square error (RMSE). A final set of QSPR models was obtained with one final model for each technique and the models were externally validated by applying a test set.

Interpreting non-linear models has always been a major challenge. However, there are several techniques to make supervised machine learning models interpretable46. In this work, the Accumulated Local Effect (ALE)54 was used to investigate the effect of each descriptor on the target variable. All initial descriptors were normalized before the model development. The normalization of descriptors was carried out using Python’s scikit-learn library55.

sec.title: Visualization
sec.p: All visualization plots and figures were obtained using Python’s matplotlib, seaborn library56 and ChemAxon Suite41.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, a comprehensive ML-based QSPR study on a large and diverse dataset of homopolymers (more than 900 polymers) with experimental glass transition temperature data collected from various sources was performed. A set of 2883 molecular descriptors was generated and curated by data analysis procedures. A feature selection was applied using a GA-MLR-based analysis and as a result 15 features were selected. Then a set of machine learning methods were applied, where the multiple linear regression and non-linear machine learning algorithms were used in a two-way approach for interpretability/predictivity modeling. In the case of the MLR model the contributions of molecular descriptors to the Tg index were analyzed and discussed, showing a high impact of the factors related to electronic effects.

Among the additional developed QSPR-ML models, the support vector machine (SVM) demonstrated the best statistically significant result, with robust and positive values of R2 of 0.813 and 0.770, for training and test set, respectively. The QSPR-SVM model showed the lowest estimation error, RMSE = 0.062. This indicates the model’s high capability of predicting the glass transition temperatures for new materials. It is worth noting that the dataset size in the present report with respect to those of previous studies is significantly larger.

Moreover, in this work with the aim to externally validate the QSPR-SVM model, a completely independent dataset was applied, having structurally different polymers extracted from SciFinder. A total of 369 precursor polymer structures were chosen, where after curation a set of 28 structures were selected to be evaluated with the SVM model. The predictions resulted in predictive R2 coefficient of 0.712, confirming the good performance of the model. The obtained result with predicted Tg values validates the current methodology for the ability of fast and adequate prediction of glass transition temperatures for new homopolymers.
Finally, the developed predictive QSPR models represent a robust ML workflow for the virtual screening and design of homopolymers with desired Tg values in a rapid way.

fn.p: Publisher’s note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: G.C-M. initiated the research, and performed the data collection, data analysis, data visualization and initial manuscript’s draft writing. A.K. performed the data curation, formal analysis, and initial manuscript’s draft writing. H.P-T. and H.G-D. performed the data analysis and contributed to discussion of results, reviewed the final version of the manuscript. B.R. supervised the research project, acquired the funding and administered the project. B.R. and D.C.W. discussed the final results, edited, reviewed and approved the final version of the manuscript. All authors have read and given their consent to the final version of the publication.

sec.title: Peer review information
sec.p: Communications Chemistry thanks the anonymous reviewers for their contribution to the peer review of this work.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The dataset used to develop the machine learning models shown in Figs. 5 and 6 is curated from published papers and listed in the Supplementary Information. The authors declare that all data supporting the findings and those used for reproducing the figures in this paper are available within the paper and its Supplementary Information. Source data are provided with this paper. Supplementary data to this article can be found online at 10.1038/s42004-024-01305-0. The developed QSPR-SVM model in this work was also deployed as Web Apps on the Streamlit platform as Tg_ML_predictor (https://mltgpredictor-9tzz6kfng8gv5luxfuomie.streamlit.app/) and available as a free resource online.

notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests
